problems.title: Introduction to Phonetics
problems.content: What is the difference between [p] and [b] sounds? Both are bilabial stops, but one is voiced and one is voiceless.
problems.officialSolution: [p] is voiceless (no vocal cord vibration), [b] is voiced (vocal cords vibrate).

problems.title: Basic Morphology
problems.content: In English, we add -s for plurals: cat→cats, dog→dogs. But some words are irregular: child→children, mouse→mice. Why?
problems.officialSolution: Irregular plurals often come from older forms of English or other Germanic languages.

problems.title: Simple Syntax Trees
problems.content: Draw a syntax tree for: "The cat sat on the mat"
problems.officialSolution: [S [NP The cat] [VP sat [PP on [NP the mat]]]]

problems.title: Language Families
problems.content: Which languages belong to the Romance family? Name at least 5.
problems.officialSolution: Spanish, French, Italian, Portuguese, Romanian (all descended from Latin)

problems.title: Semantic Shift
problems.content: The English word "silly" used to mean "blessed" or "innocent" in Middle English. How do words change meaning over time?
problems.officialSolution: Semantic shift occurs through metaphor, metonymy, specialization, generalization, and social factors. "Silly" shifted from blessed → innocent → naive → foolish.

problems.title: Swahili Noun Classes
problems.content: Swahili nouns are grouped into classes. Given: mtoto/watoto (child/children), mtu/watu (person/people), kikapu/vikapu (basket/baskets). What are the plural forms of: mkulima (farmer), kikombe (cup)?
problems.officialSolution: wakulima (farmers), vikombe (cups). Swahili uses noun class prefixes: m-/wa- for people, ki-/vi- for objects.

problems.title: Greek Alphabet Origins
problems.content: The Greek alphabet was adapted from the Phoenician script. What major innovation did the Greeks introduce to the writing system?
problems.officialSolution: The Greeks added vowel letters. Phoenician only had consonants. Greek converted some Phoenician consonant letters (like aleph→alpha for A) into vowels, creating the first true alphabet.
